Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Evolving Coordinated Quadruped Gaits with the 
	HyperNEAT Generative Encoding
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770313; y=KIEhx9_Z0yMLmOTA1dQ3ykPK5OgUUHlSVbFgmfnYBGsc5kCaNhJH
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Hi Jeff,

Thanks for posting the paper, nice work. It's another clear win for
HyperNEAT and in an area with commercialisation opportunities I would
suggest.

Some thoughts:

2009/2/15 Jeff Clune <jclune@...>:

> 1) Biped gaits are harder to evolve than quadruped gaits.

I think most would agree that biped is more difficult because of the
need to maintain balance, something which probably requires slightly
different strategies for different speeds - certainly between walking
and running - and for acceleration and deceleration.


> 2) The sine wave I provided made it really easy to evolve periodic gaits
[...]
> As a side note, I tried to evolve the period for a short while and it was a
> miserable failure.

Was the period encoded into each genome or a global experiment
variable? Perhaps you could try using one of the free outputs as the
sine wave period?


> 3) Leaky integrators hurt performance for some reason.

I suspect the need for them is reduced by your use of a PID
controller. Without a hard coded PID controller on each joint the
leaky integrators may allow the neural net to evolve that
functionality, and perhaps improve on the standard PID approach.

Also if we were using a recursive neural net then leaky integrators
should (I think) allow the network to generate a since wave
internally, thus removing the need for an externally provided wave.

Colin.
